comments.commentBody:
My second daughter came two weeks before her due date. I worked the day before she was born. I thought I was having Braxton-Hicks contractions as I had for the previous seven months, but no, they were the real ones. I woke up the next morning around 4:00 a.m.; my water had broken and those apparent Braxton-Hicks contractions kept occurring every two minutes or so. I called my hospital, which was two hours away (in a big city with a NICU, unlike where I live), and they told me to go to the local hospital, so I did, through a flood, we were probably the last car through, and she was born at 6:53 to the hands of people I'd never met before. All was well.

Oh, actually, my first daughter was born like that, too. I had been seeing a midwife, but then five weeks before she was due, I suddenly developed very severe pre-eclampsia, so they transferred care that Thursday, of one of my pre-natal appointments, and she was induced starting Friday and finally arrived on Sunday. I went through many shifts of doctors and nurses whom I had never met before. Actually that experience was why I was going to that hospital for pre-natal care for the second one.

And now they have a pediatrician not associated with any of this at all.

Similar to the author, what I wanted was for my children to be born in California; they would have been 6th generation. But they were born in Oregon, where they are perhaps 4th or 5th generation. I'll have to ask my spouse. But it doesn't matter.

Susan Anderson, Boston, Oct 10th post

Dear Ms. Anderson,

Remind me, please, how many bullets struck Ms. Anjali Appaduai in Durban?

It is good that you linked to Ms. Appadurai's rant. It illustrates with crystal clarity just how trivial, hysterical, sanctimonious, and laughably self-righteous "climate change activism" is, compared to the real heroics it takes to defy a pack of armed religious fanatics.

So Anjali Appadurai was "briefly banned from Durban for speaking from the heart."

And for that you seriously propose to mention Anjali Appadurai in the same breath as Malala Yousafzai?

The comparison fails so completely it descends to the ludicrous.

After months of vicious intimidation, Ms. Malala Yousafzai was shot in the head.

It is a miracle that she survived to continue her valiant struggle for education against the resurgence of barbarism with which she found herself surrounded.

A miracle.

By contrast, Ms. Appadurai's air-conditioned jet ride to Durban and her subsequent risk-free decision to make a nuisance of herself there rates, in my opinion, as the act of a spoiled self-righteous brat intent on polishing her halo.

@ Rollo — The general perspective of your remarks is well-considered. But the specific argument about fitness level strikes me as a little disingenuous. Obviously, if fitness level were the overriding criterion for selection, the coaching staff could have simply had the players run through tests for aerobic capacity, and select the guys with the top marks. Any coach worth Klinsmann's salary, however, has to know that the process of putting together a winning team is vastly more complicated than that.

Donovan probably was not able to run the field for 90 minutes quite like those guys on the roster in their late teens and early 20s. (Nor, surely, were Davis, Dempsey, or Wondo . . . .) But there's never been any credible suggestion that he was dreadfully out of shape, or unfit to meet the competitive rigors of the tournament. And no one has argued that he should have been placed on the roster as a sentimental gesture. To the contrary, as many have rationally argued, Donovan offered a wealth of skills and experience that might have provided the team with playmaking and attacking flexibility to meet unexpected circumstances — such as the injury to Altidore.

Simplistic arguments that assert Donovan failed to meet some fitness standard superseding all other considerations smack of an attempt to evade what is, in the end, the undeniable strangeness of the decision to leave him off the squad.

— Brian
The same can be said for JK's performance. Is the team better. Talking only about future player development protects coaches only.

The distance is not surprising -- one man is about the past and the other is only about the future.

But they both share the trait that they are not going to lie to make someone happy and are only going to give an honest answer.

To me LD has a great US record and deserves his due.

But JK's strength is what he gets killed for -- turning over the roster searching for new players. How can he stress from day one that fitness is a top priority and you have to earn your spot everyday and then say except for this guy -- who gets a lifetime achievement appointment.

Klinsmann doesn't reminisce. The past, the present are not good enough -- everybody has to get better.

Martin, if WUSS had been considered as a dialect form of WORSE, I don't think Will would have had them cohabit the same grid, and in almost symmetric positions to boot.

Interesting discussion, but no matter how you decorate it, most of us will recognize the Palinesque lipstick on a pig.

Thanks for the link, John. Always instructive to return to original sources. I'm sure by now Chaos has fixed the distinction between 'palpate' and 'palpitate', as well as Canada vs Canadian geese. (Ducking and ambling slowly out of range)

The comment I liked came later, from an onlooker:
This diner thing is the stupidest "discussion" or, more accurately, display of one-upsmanship I've seen on this board. There is no rock solid definition of the word "diner" or what constitutes a diner. Some have jukeboxes, I guess. Some have a counter and stools. Some serve sh**ty coffee. They probably all serve eggs, unless it happens to be a day when the topic du jour is not earthy authenticity and is instead ultra-correctness, in which case you'll all be claiming never to have eaten anything except vegetables grown by peace-loving organic farmers who play Liszt for their cabbage.

**substituted courtesy of the emu-loving LF

To be fair, if I'm going to edit, I should also address the bystander's last sentence. Unless those farmers actually have a second job as classically-trained musicians, that last sentence should read 'play Liszt to their cabbages'.

ps. I'm Offenbach.
Martin, See 37D: WUSS?  That's Chaos (whatever number he uses).

YOu don't have to be bright to be manuverd. The "supreme" court was formed by Bush to serve the interests of his silent conservative supporters. Look how many congressmen/women are millionaires, even from poorer districts. How did this happen? By careful, hidden  campaign contributions. Voting for the candidates who seem to spend the least amount of money won't help. Ooordinary citizens will become pawns in the hands of these silent people. Those of us   who are able to see though the lies, half truths, etc are lucky. There are barely four weeks to black out the lies.

The Supreme Court justices are certainly not the brightest jurists in the country, but even they must have known that the floodgates of secret money would open with the Citizens United decision. But they care more about their agendas than they care about the country.
If this is allowed to continue, our democracy will enter a death spiral. To the politician, election has become an end in itself, not a means to serve the people. But what can ordinary citizens do? Can we just ignore the outright lies, half-truths, scurrilous attacks and counter-attacks that fill the airwaves? Maybe we could vote for the candidates spending the least amount of money and show the venal politicians the doors of the Capitol, forever keeping them out.

Our costs with insurance were in the thousands of dollars, given an 80/20 split between insurance versus patient responsibility.  And these are with a really excellent benefits plan.  It required some financial planning, and spacing our children so that I had sick leave during FMLA (for part of it).  Because the policy was that I had to use my entire sick leave during FMLA and couldn't reserve any out of it, when I went back to work and my daughter went to daycare at age six months, I had no accrued leave for her many illnesses and mine her first two years.

It is difficult for me to negotiate in an economy where one is grateful for a job. I would like to see a study on gender and the perception of job scarcity and labor interchangeability. As a female attorney in the nonprofit sector, I know that some employers receive hundreds of excellent applications for one position. Why should they choose me? And if they choose me, how do I dare quantify my worth at a rate higher than the salary they've set? Do men tend to feel this way too? Or would most men selected for a coveted position still feel entitled to negotiate their salary because, circularly, they have been selected so they must be the best?

I also wonder if women are expected to be especially grateful for the patronage of male employers. My female friends and I have had potential employers (both nonprofit and corporate, all male) ask us to bid against other unknown attorney applicants by telling the potential employer the *lowest* salary we'd take. Yes, we were invited to negotiate our salary----negotiate a lower one.
I suspect the emus wouldn't even let me name my favorite character.
No, not bad for everyone.  Bad for someone who was presumed guilty, treated as such, and ultimately still has suspicions hanging around him like a bad odor although no charges will be filed.

The great thing about Perry Mason was that; not only did he get his client off, he would also find the real guilty party.  Sadly, life is not that simple.  This accusation will probably hang over this guy forever, and we will never find out who is the real culprit (assuming it actually occurred and assuming it is not him).  Bad for everyone.

Agree. I don't know how much Cashman had to do with not paying Cano for 10 years but that decision became idiotic when they signed Carlos Beltran for three years. I hated to see Cano go but I didn't want to see the Yankees saddled with another ARod contract. But if you're going to pay Beltran a ridiculous amount of money now to play into his 40s, why didn't you just pay Cano a ridiculous amount of money in seven years? Sure, Cano was looking for considerably more than Beltran, but at least you would have kept one of the best hitters in the AL during his peak production years. And who knows, by 2021, $25 mil a year might be chump change.
Cashman's first move should be to fire himself.

Cashman has benefited by the decisions of others during the run of success of the late 90’s and early part of the following decade. His decisions going alone have been suspect with overpaying on long-term deals for players past their prime. The farm team that delivered the early run of success has been derelict with position player talent for nearly a decade and Cashman has to carry some of the blame.  The Yankees continue to age and not improve and it gets worse next year. It is past time to dump Cashman.

I agree.  Given that Israel controls the sea, the air, and the crossings into and out of Gaza (with the exception of the entry to Egypt which, given that Egypt is now more aligned with Israel, might as well be Israeli-controlled), the Israelis are the de facto rulers of the region.  Gaza functions like a rebellious province of Israel rather than a neighboring state.  That makes the Israelis responsible for the well-being of the people of Gazans and responsible for repairing what they blow up.
I don't think it's "potential."  It's ACTUAL.

Maybe you should read David Brook's column from this week:
http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/10/opinion/david-brooks-money-matters-les...

Thank you, Nicholas Confessore and the NYT, for laying the facts out there about the anonymous campaign contributions.  The usual litany most often heard is, "Both Democrats and Republicans do it."  But Mr. Confessore has made it abundantly clear that the Republicans have benefited significantly more than the Democrats from the Citizens United decision which basically allows huge amounts of anonymous money to potentially buy our democracy.

The side by side charts in the article showing the price fluctuations of the SP500 and crude oil should dishearten those who expect strong economic growth. The declining slope of the crude oil chart may contain a message about the current state of the world and US economies.

If these economies were growing, oil prices would be stable or slightly higher. Lower (declining) prices for crude reflect stagnant, stalled, or declining economic growth. Growing economies still require more oil, not less, and the lower price is based on lower demand. That declining price sends the message that the stock market indices will catch up to, eventually.

Prices in these commodities markets don't lie, and rarely give false signals. They often portend, or augur, depending on your point of view, inflation or deflation. Government spending is declining, quantitative is ending gradually but certainly, wages stagnant to declining depending on which period of time is evaluated, and funds that might be used to fuel economic growth have been sequestered for a couple of years now by bad fiscal policy in Congress. There should be no surprises if the SP price chart quickly begins to look like the chart of crude shown if it becomes apparent that economic growth has stalled.

Just read the book, shallow and self-satisfied. - Panetta started out as a competent bureau of the budget director and then ran the Peter Principle route, promoted to the level of his incompetence at the CIA (read his tortuous explanation of torture -- he's against it, but it was done with the best of intentions, something like that). Then promoted once again as Secretary of Defense.

The comparison with Bob Gates and Hilary Clinton is ill-taken. They are serious people who did serious work at Defense and State respectively. Agree or disagree with their criticism of certain Presidential decisions. they treated Obama and the office with respect, not so Panetta who comes off as an increasingly empty suit.

By uncritically according Panetta the undeserved status of a wise man (read the book; it is self-serving and shallow) the media has inflated his importance. The President is to be criticized all right, for choosing Panetta who stands in relation to Obama as another self-inflated pol, James Byrnes, stood to Truman.

Let me add another specific to the criticisms of the book in the commentary: Panetta's cursory treatment of Latin America as a subset of the Middle East, where a handful of Hizbullah supporters in a remote corner of South America get more of his attention than energy, migration, or the transnational criminal syndicates, which have turned parts of the region into a war zone.

I hate to state the obvious, but if you don't have the courage of your convictions then I'd say you certainly don't belong anywhere as a professor.
While generally of a liberal bent, I have no tolerance for political correctness on campuses, whether of the right or the left.

Remember 2012 and the one term Obama? Load up Congress with the stupid party (pers. comment, B. Jindal, 2013) and see what kind of legislation we get. You would think it couldn't get worse than this but give the pubs the majority and watch it get worse. They couldn't even agree on impeachment.

The last serious effort at campaign finance reform were done by Maccain-Feingold and their efforts were overturned by the Supreme Court. There is a lot of blame assigned to the Court in this Comments section, however if the Congress passes a law that does not violate the Constitution (according to the Court) or even an Amendment (in which case the Court can't really do anything) then campaign finance reform can actually happen.
So the power is not really in the hands of the Court (which is getting blamed a lot) but in the hands of the Congress. Also it is good to remember that whereas Obama promised in 2007 to accept public financing, in 2008 he reneged when he realized that he would raise more money than McCain. If we keep electing politicians like this there will never be any campaign finance reform.
What the Supreme Court has put in place is "secret money" overwhelming local congressional elections. Common sense sees that this unjust.
Senators face elections every six years, Representatives every two.

Here in Richmond California, Chevron Oil has spent 1.9M on a local election campaign through their PAC from a war chest of 4M. Richmond has a total population of 107K. This level of spending for largely negative and hateful campaigning against city council and mayoral candidates is unconscionable and needs to cease immediately. When even small local elections like this receive this much corporate bullying, democracy becomes a joke. Overturn Citizens United now!
The 1980 platform sounds pretty good to me.

What a great system. Canada you got this right! I doubt the founding fathers could ever imagined how twisted their democracy has become!  All the money spent on campaigns (or even a fraction) could be so much better spent - such as finding a cure and positive treatment for Ebola, now a worldwide threat including one to the U.S. One could name more than 10 other things such funding could alleviate, but human greed overrides all human needs. What a pity!

$100 limit per candidate and/or issue per cycle per breathing American and every Tax Paying American can allocate $100 more of their Tax Bill to the Candidate/Issue of their choice.

No Congress critter will jump through hoops for $100.

I understand your point, and, I, too, do not care to share political opinions with employers. But for the large amounts that are buying influence there should be disclosure. I'm assuming you're not trying to buy influence with your political donations?
Can't  do that! This a "free" country! The "supreme court" said so.

Start a petition.
1) All political communications must be proceeded with a written or verbal list of potential conflicts of interest, much like our scientists do today.
2) Wipe the term, "Political contributions" from the dictionary and discussion...replace with "bribes".
3) Limit the time and money spent on Federal and State campaigns.
